BE11:06am

Commerzbank und Deutsche Bank haben heute entschieden, die Gespräche über einen Zusammenschluss beider Institute nicht fortzusetzen. Nach gründlicher Prüfung hat sich herausgestellt, dass ein solcher Zusammenschluss nicht im Interesse der Aktionäre beider Unternehmen sowie anderer Interessengruppen wäre.

„Es war sinnvoll, diese Option einer innerdeutschen Konsolidierung zu prüfen. Für uns war aber von Anfang an klar: Mit einem Zusammenschluss müssten wir höhere und nachhaltigere Renditen für unsere Aktionäre erreichen und die Leistungen für unsere Kunden verbessern können“, sagt Martin Zielke, Vorstandsvorsitzender der Commerzbank. „Nach gründlicher Analyse sind wir zum Schluss gekommen, dass ein Zusammenschluss mit der Deutschen Bank keinen ausreichenden Mehrwert bieten würde – auch mit Blick auf die Umsetzungsrisiken, Restrukturierungskosten und Kapitalanforderungen, die mit einer solch großen Integration einhergehen. Christian Sewing und allen Beteiligten möchte ich für die vertrauensvollen Gespräche in den vergangenen Wochen danken. Commerzbank bleibt bei ihrer Strategie. Wir werden unser Wachstum gemeinsam mit unseren Kunden vorantreiben und konsequent in die Zukunft investieren.“

BE11:12am

In our opinion, the failure of merger talks with Commerzbank highlights
the strategic challenges which DB is facing for a variety of reasons.
Firstly, while there would have been multiple pressure points which
could have dictated the ultimate failure of the proposed merger, we think
that the lack of shareholder sponsorship would have likely been one of
the more relevant. However this should not be a surprise considering the
scant reward that DB has offered to shareholders for the circa €27bn of
capital raised since 2010, as compared to the current €17.5bn market
cap. While the capital position with CET1 at 13.6% as at FY’18 appears
adequate, we note that it is down from the 14.8% (YE’17), highlighting
the challenges of generating organic capital given the weak earnings.
Secondly, we note that the resistance from unions to the merger also
highlights the challenges in being able to materially reduce costs,
which had been DB’s main strategic plan on which they had executed
with mixed success. While we expect that DB management may offer
more cost synergies to appease the market, we think that the failure to
agree a merger highlights the difficulties in implementing cost savings.
Thirdly, the failure to build a stronger domestic business with the
merger highlights the question of where the revenues will come given
a further requirement to de-risk the IB. Lastly, we think that there will
be continued pressure from the ratings agencies on the Non-
Preferred Senior (Baa3/Negative Outlook), whereas a merger would
have clearly reset the ratings agency clock on ratings actions. As a result
of the above strategic challenges, we downgrade DB to Neutral from
Overweight (5Yr Senior CDS 148/156bp).

BE11:16am

CBK: Alternative suitors – no rush for UCG/ING to get involved, in our view
Previously, press reports have indicated that UCG was considering a bid for CBK (FT, April 4); last week (April 16) press reports (Manager Magazin) wrote that
ING was also considering a potential bid for CBK, including offering to relocate the Group headquarters to Frankfurt as part of any potential combination. We
have previously estimated (see link here) that a UCG/CBK combination could result in an ROI of 14.6% in 2021 assuming cost savings at 30% of HBV’s cost
base but would likely require an additional EUR5bn in capital which would translate into a 20% increase in share count. In addition, we estimate the potential
deal (including the capital increase) would result in a 12% EPS dilution by 2021, which we do not find attractive.
We would therefore prefer UCG management to continue its focus on the de-risking of its Non-Core portfolio and organic cost reduction. In the case of ING, we
see the bank’s digital led strategy as a key differentiator and would prefer it to continue to deliver on its organic growth path as outlined during its Investor Day last month.

BE11:16am

DBK
There have been press reports about material share issuance to finance a potential deal (FT, 28th March 2019) and that overhang might be removed if the deal
fails. The question is whether DBK will announce a more material strategic update now and what that could be. DBK targets an at least 4% ROTE in 2019 but
consensus only forecasts 1.5%. The risk is that a potential strategic update will be either long dated or shorter dated but might come with material upfront
costs.

BE11:18am

[W]hat alternatives does DBK have? We estimate DB to make 2.3% ROTE in 2019, compared to target 4%+, i.e. not earning COE and hence we see L-T implications in a market downturn scenario, resulting in credit market concerns. Hence, we saw the CBK merger financed through badwill, a preferable option calming credit markets despite execution risk, considering: 1) a potential merger with CBK would have led to DB becoming c55% retail/commercial banking with a pro-forma market share in Germany of c11%; and 2) more importantly, a German government stake in a combined entity with a pro-forma shareholding of c6% which we welcomed. Despite better than expected results by DBK vs consensus in its pre-announcement, we assume DB requires further restructuring. DB states it is “reviewing all alternatives”. In our view, plan B is more likely to be implemented on a DB standalone basis of restructuring the equity business and further asset reduction. We estimate DB loses €200mn-300mn pretax in the US Equities business. However, even if these estimated losses were absent, this would result in only 0.4% net ROTE improvement – still well below CoE.
Hence, we expect potential plan B measures to be too little to generate adequate ROE for DB and we would potentially need more substantial measures to improve ROE generation going forward. This could lead to further restructuring of the CIB operation consuming 2/3rd capital and generating 1% ROE. However, DB does not currently have a stable ROE businesses as it makes only 4% ROE in 2019E with its retail/WM operation (PCB).
DB needs to take further steps in respect to costs, in our view, considering the difficult revenue environment which is much tougher than expected. DB targets 4.4% cost reduction and an estimated additional c2% p.a. from 2020-21E – we believe there is further potential to adjust the cost base.
For CBK, we see an acquisition as the more likely outcome at this point. Recent press articles mention ING and UniCredit (Source: Commerzbank Rises After Drawing Takeover Interest From ING – Bloomberg, April 16th 2019; UniCredit eyes bid for Commerzbank if Deutsche talks fail – Reuters, 4th April 2019). CBK trades at 7.2x P/E, 0.4x P/TBV for 4.9% RoTE in 2021E.

BE11:32am

Against a stable but relatively high rate of build cost inflation (3-4% per annum for the last 2+ years) TW now says that this has risen to 5%. This is manageable if selling prices are rising but they are not – the statement indicates Q1 as flat against Q4. We estimate that for TW build costs account for 56% of the average selling price so prices need to rise like-for-like by 2.8% to hold margins steady. If pricing is flat, that additional cost burden drops out of the margin on a point-for-point basis.

The impact of costs on margins will be softened by the high forward sales position which will defer the impact but by H2 of FY2019F we would expect to see the lack of price rises and the higher costs gnawing away at the gross and EBIT margins. This has been our thesis on the house builders for some time that while demand may be stable (mainly due to Help to Buy we feel) it is going to be hard for all house builders to sustain margins.

BE11:32am

he previous commentary from the sector and the forecast consensus has been too bullish, in our view, and this statement confirms that it is right to be looking for at least a fade in PBT here rather than sustained growth. This has been our position for some time, but we may now look to pencil in a higher rate of PBT decline.

We had been expecting some more structured comments on the dividend but instead we just have soft guidance that, all things remaining equal, total dividends will remain at close to current levels of £600m total or c.18.6p per share. All things may not, however, be equal.

Overall, this statement is weaker than the market will have been expecting with the double header of weaker pricing and higher costs. While the higher sales rate may deliver fractionally more unit sales than expected, any hit to margins would more than offset that. Our existing forecast for FY2019F is for PBT to drop for £856m to £815m and this early in the year we are OK with that but there could now be a steeper decline in FY2020. We are currently forecasting a drop to £788m.

BE11:33am

We think it is time to call time on our positive stance on the house builders after another negative report on house prices. The ‘official’ house price index (HPI) from Land Registry has dropped to a seven year low with an annual rate in February of +0.6%. This overall UK figure is flattered by the non-English markets and England, where most new homes are built, showed annual inflation of just +0.4%. This market reading squares with Nationwide’s HPI and the views of Estate Agents in the RICS survey. We refer to the last RICS survey which suggested house prices would, in its view, fall for another six months. Based on the weak pricing environment, we still see the risk of earnings shocks from the house builders as under-estimated and after a strong relative performance in Q1 of 2019, we are stepping back our recommendations moving Barratt, Bovis and Taylor Wimpey from Buy to SELL and all other recommendations to HOLD.

Also factoring in market leader Tesco gaining momentum and investing in prices ahead of the market, we are over 10% below FY20e PBT company-compiled consensus, which assumes no change to SBRY’s existing strategy is announced next week. BE11:41am

Irony of ironies
There was a considerable sense of irony that the CMA announced its final decision on the proposed Sainsbury-Asda merger ahead of its self-imposed deadline of the 30th April. That irony emerges from the fact that Sainsbury and Asda took the CMA to the Competition Appeals Tribunal (CAT) to argue that there was the need for more time to consider a deal where the players felt that they knew the rules better than the referee.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Arrogance and naivety do not prevail
Well, the referee has now blown the whistle on a deal that we give credit to its architect(s) for being bold but were set against a strategy and tactics that were most certainly not of a mould of the likes of Sir Alex Ferguson. Indeed, arrogance and naivety are words that come to mind when considering this proposed amalgamation from start to finish.

Tony Scott I suspect that Sainsburys would bring down the allure of shopping at a 'luxury brand' like M&S and might force shoppers towards Waitroses etc?
BE11:42am

Lacking rationality and perspective
At the heart of the proposed deal's problems is an incorrect and over-extrapolation of the decision by the CMA, under a different managerial regime, to unconditionally clear the Tesco-Booker merger. We felt at the time that it was a surprising and poor decision. However, rather than analysing matters with a sense of rationality and perspective, Sainsbury and Asda seem to have decided that 1+1 can equal 10.

Bluesky21 Tesco always show up with the larger £ loss to discounters in Kantar data, but adjusted for their larger size they are doing ok
BE11:42am

Asymmetrical analysis and gallery talking
From this mis-calculation, the merger parties did not assess the change of the guard at the CMA, most particularly the new Chair, Andrew Tyrie. Furthermore, in not being a merger of two domestically listed entities the justification of the proposal involved much asymmetry and talking to the galleries.
The asymmetry revolved around the fact that Sainsbury and Asda revealed that they are struggling to compete against the limited assortment supermarkets (LASs) and the likes of Amazon, even though the latter barely registers on the radar of British supermarket activity, and yet their plight should be accepted by the CMA when the ramifications of the deal for the supply chain, which seemed to go through a volte face following the provisional findings, should not.

BE11:48am

Sirius has today announced the European Offtake agreement it has been flagging for some time. This is a 10-year supply and distribution agreement with BayWa Agri Supply and Trade B.V. The guaranteed minimum POLY4 volumes under the Agreement increase to 2.5 Mtpa in year five taking Sirius’ aggregate peak contracted sales volume to 10.7Mtpa (12.1 Mtpa with customer options). POLY4 is the processed form of polyhalite – a naturally occurring mineral which forms the resource at its Woodsmith mine project in North Yorkshire – the mineral contains potassium, calcium, magnesium and sulphur, 4 of the 6 macro nutrients essential for healthy plant growth.

BayWa is a publicly-listed entity (ETR:BYW6) headquartered in Munich, with revenues of EUR16bn (2018). The group distributes over 30Mtpa of agricultural goods across Europe including sales of approximately 2.0Mtpa of fertilizers. The pricing for the contract is structured such that Sirius gets a share of the reference price that BayWa sells at – and BayWa is therefore incentivised to get as higher price as possible and sell the product down the chain closer to the farm gate. Sirius expects this partnership approach to pricing to deliver the highest POLY4 price out of its suite of offtake agreements.

Sirius continues to develop its Woodsmith mine in North Yorkshire and as well as the sinking of the shafts has recently began tunnel boring for the Mineral Transport System which will carry POLY4 from mine to plant underneath the North Yorkshire countryside. The final piece of the jigsaw is the $3bn debt funding and we expect news from this shortly. Ultimately, Sirius will be a large cash flow generator, delivering natural fertilizer across the world from its unique deposit of polyhalite in North Yorkshire.

BE12:13pm

GVC Holdings PLC (LSE: GVC), the global sports-betting and gaming group and owner of Ladbrokes and Coral, has today called for an end to all UK sports-betting broadcast advertising, at any time of the day, on live and repeated sporting events (exempting horseracing). Under GVC’s proposals advertising specifically promoting responsible gambling and safer gambling campaigns would be permitted, but strictly limited to one advertisement per commercial break.

The call goes far further than the forthcoming pre-watershed, whistle-to-whistle advertising ban which is set to be introduced at the start of the 2019-20 football season in August. While GVC helped to bring about the new restrictions, the Company believes they do not go far enough, and is therefore calling on its industry peers to join it in helping to revolutionise the marketing of gambling brands.

12:13 pm
BE12:14pm

In addition to the call for a broadcast advertising ban, the Group is also today announcing further initiatives, as part of its Changing for the Bettor safer gambling campaign to tackle the issue of gambling related harm head-on. These include:

Shirt sponsorship and perimeter advert ban – GVC has today committed to unilaterally ending all shirt sponsorship deals with UK football teams and banning match-side hoardings adverts at football grounds, to allow fans to watch their favourite teams without seeing any incentives to bet. The Company is calling on the industry and the football governing bodies to also take action in this area.

Increased investment in RET – Having been the first and only operator to commit to doubling spending on RET (Research, Education and Treatment) to 0.2% of UK gross gambling revenue in 2019, GVC has today committed to raising this to 1% by 2022 – ten times the current requirement.

Treatment centres – GVC is establishing a new independent trust with the aim of making charitable contributions to fund treatment of problem gambling. The Leon House treatment centre in Manchester has been identified as the first preferred recipient.

Safer gambling software - To help those customers that are struggling with their gambling, we will offer the GamBan software, free to any individual who is showing signs of problematic play.

BE12:14pm

Commenting on the new proposals, GVC’s CEO, Kenny Alexander said:

“Whilst the vast majority of our customers enjoy our products responsibly, it is high time that the industry did more to protect its customers from potential harm. As the UK’s largest gambling company, and owner of Ladbrokes and Coral, we at GVC are doing exactly that. I call on our industry peers to help us bring about an end to broadcast advertising which promotes sports-betting in the UK no matter the time of day.”

“Increasing investment in research, education and treatment ten-fold by 2022, funding treatment centres and using technology to intervene before a problem develops, alongside our existing behavioural analytics, brings to life our commitment to be the most trusted and enjoyable betting operator in the world.”

“The industry should and can do more to protect the vulnerable, and today’s announcement demonstrates GVC’s commitment to delivering on that.”
